summary: A Suspicious Activity Report filed by The Charles Schwab Corporation regarding suspicious wire transfers totaling over $27 million from accounts linked to Jeffrey Epstein and his associates in June-July 2019, coinciding with Epstein's arrest. The report details attempts to send large sums to Morocco for real estate, concerns about Epstein being a flight risk, and the subsequent reversal of some transactions.

events.title: Account Relationships Established
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and associated entities (Southern Trust Company, etc.) establish relationships and accounts with Charles Schwab & Co., Inc.

events.title: First Large Wire Transfer Request
events.description: Schwab receives a request to send 11,150,000 Euros ($12,708,324 USD) to Marc Leon in Morocco from a Southern Trust Company account, signed by both an associate and Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Wire Reversal Requested
events.description: An associate calls Schwab to request reversal of the 11,150,000 Euro wire, citing renegotiated terms on a real estate deal. The wire is later successfully retracted at a loss.

events.title: Second Large Wire Transfer Request
events.description: Schwab receives a second request to send $14,950,000 USD to Marc Leon in Morocco, again signed by an associate and Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Arrested on Federal Charges
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is arrested and federally charged with one count of sex trafficking of minors and one count of conspiracy to engage in sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Funds Returned, Wire Cancelled
events.description: The retracted wire funds from June 26 are deposited back into the Southern Trust Company account. An associate confirms the cancellation of the July 4 $14.95M wire request.

events.title: Scheduled Bail Hearing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's bail hearing is scheduled for this date, a key event cited by Schwab as raising concerns about him being a flight risk.

keyFacts: In June-July 2019, shortly before and after Jeffrey Epstein's arrest, attempts were made to wire over $27 million from his associated accounts to Marc Leon in Morocco for real estate purposes.
Charles Schwab filed this SAR due to concerns about Epstein being a "very high flight risk" given his wealth and international ties, and the timing of the large transfers around his arrest.
One wire for 11,150,000 Euros was successfully reversed after a request from an associate, resulting in a $113,527.80 loss due to currency conversion.
The accounts under review were funded through transfers from entities like Deutsche Bank Trust, FirstBank, Coatue Enterprises LLC, and individuals Darren Indyke & Michelle Saipher.
Jeffrey Epstein is listed as the 100% beneficial owner but did not have authority to act on the Schwab accounts; an associate was the authorized agent.
